body:
Thanks for creating the issue and volunteering to work on this! 

I think you already identified the main parts of the code where changes would have to be implemented: the handling of observation (oh) and forecasting horizons (fh). 

Adding support for date time indices will also require a lot more extensive unit testing. Some package that we interface may not support date time indexing (e.g. [pmdarima](https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima) as far as I remember).

As far as I've seen, the arima class of the pmdarima package wraps the statsmodel's ARIMA. And it appears that statsmodels supports date time indexing. Source : https://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/1.0.0/_modules/pmdarima/arima/arima.html

I will do elaborate Unit testing anyway after making appropriate code changes. Can you please assign this to me?

@mloning, would it perhaps also be a good time to think about the API and use of indices? Currently, the API is integer index (`iloc`) based, and time indices are ignored both in application of algorithms, and in the horizon interface, if I'm not mistaken. Shall we think about specs?

Alright @mloning, @shruthibalaji2307, I made a proposal on how support for datetime indices could look here, please have a look at [this wiki page](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/wiki/Design-proposal:-forecasting-API-re-work-including-support-for-datetime-indices).

There are two versions, and the "luxurious" version relies on a bit o a re-work of input/output checks that allow for multiple input/output types, I've also added a [design for that](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/wiki/Design-proposal%3A-multi-type-input-output) to the wiki.

Comments and criticism very much appreciated. 
I'd prefer the luxurious version, but it might be a bit of work to implement.

body:
Hello @fkiraly , I took a look at your design document. As I was going through the sktime repository, I was also inclining toward something along the lines of the luxurious implementation you have mentioned.

However, I was wondering how the input types like dataframes (univariate/multivariate) will be passed on to the [statsmodel](https://www.statsmodels.org/stable/index.html)/[pmdarima](http://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/) forecasters during fit and predict. I know that [pmdarima](http://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/) accepts a pandas series with a datetime index as input. But how will dataframes be handled?

>However, I was wondering how the input types like dataframes (univariate/multivariate) will be passed on to the statsmodel/pmdarima forecasters during fit and predict. I know that pmdarima accepts a pandas series with a datetime index as input. But how will dataframes be handled?

Well, if a given model can't handle it, it will/should/might throw an error, e.g., a `ValueError` "this model cannot handle multivariate series :-(" or similar. If it can, a vendor/external interface would convert it to the machine format the interfaced method likes.

Perhaps we also want to have some estimator tags on what inputs an implemented methods can handle, similar to the experimental `sklearn` [estimator tags](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/developers/develop.html#estimator-tags).

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
#347, #220

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* Support for `pd.DatetimeIndex`, `pd.PeriodIndex` in data and forecasting horizon, including helper functions to patch mathematical operations on pandas date/time objects for our purposes (mostly returning integers for known time unit, rather than time delta objects)
* Included forecasting data sets are now returned with `pd.PeriodIndex`
* Support for absolute forecasting horizon specification via refactored `ForecastingHorizon` class
* Easy importing via `sktime.forecasting.all` module enabling `from sktime.forecasting.all import *` following [fastai](https://www.fast.ai/2020/02/13/fastai-A-Layered-API-for-Deep-Learning/)
* A few minor changes (typos, formatting, etc)
* Corresponding updates to forecasting notebook
* New unit tests for supported combinations of data index types and forecasting types

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 
* seaborn (soft dependency, for plotting) 

#### Key files to review 
Since the forecasting horizon was used in basically every forecasting algorithm, this PR makes changes to many files. Key changes include:

* `sktime/forecasting/base/_fh.py` (implementation of forecasting horizon class)
* `sktime/forecasting/base/tests/test_fh.py` (unit tests for forecasting horizon class)
* `sktime/forecasting/tests/_config.py` (check SUPPORTED_INDEX_FH_COMBINATIONS)
* `sktime/forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py` (unit testing framework for all forecasters)
* `sktime/utils/datetime.py` (date/time helper functions)

#### Comments
* Supporting only `pd.PeriodIndex` and not `pd.DatetimeIndex` would make the code a bit simpler as `pd.DatetimeIndex` requires additional patches to return integers for durations/time deltas and additional type distinctions (dispatch), however it seems like `pd.DatetimeIndex` supports some functionality which is not supported by `pd.PeriodIndex` (e.g. `is_month_end`)

#### Future work
* refactor `BaseLastWindowForecaster` and reduce inheritance as much as possible
